title: 110_s1672
content: The VA Vision Scholars Act of 2007 establishes the Visual Impairment and Orientation and Mobility Professionals Education Assistance Program under Chapter 80 of title 38, United States Code. The VA Vision Scholars Act of 2007 establishes a scholarship program to provide financial assistance for individuals studying visual impairment or orientation and mobility at accredited educational institutions in a State. The scholarship program established under the VA Vision Scholars Act of 2007 aims to increase the supply of qualified blind rehabilitation specialists for the Department and the Nation. The Secretary will publicize the program to educational institutions nationwide, with a focus on Hispanic-serving institutions and Historically Black Colleges and Universities. To apply for the scholarship program, individuals must submit an application to the Secretary. To participate in the scholarship program, individuals must submit an application to the Secretary along with an agreement for obligated service in the Department in exchange for educational assistance. The Secretary will provide application and agreement forms with a summary of rights and liabilities, as well as terms and conditions. Upon approval by the Secretary, individuals are notified in writing and become participants in the scholarship program. The financial assistance provided covers tuition and fees as determined necessary by the Secretary. The financial assistance provided under this chapter covers tuition and fees necessary for individuals, including those pursuing dual degrees. It can supplement other educational assistance as long as the total amount received does not exceed the total tuition and fees for the academic year. The maximum amount of assistance is determined by the Secretary. The maximum amount of educational assistance provided under this chapter is $15,000 for full-time students and is prorated for part-time students. The total assistance provided to an individual cannot exceed $45,000, and the duration of assistance is determined by the Secretary. The Secretary may provide financial assistance to an individual for up to six years under this chapter. An agreement between the Secretary and a participant in the scholarship program must be in writing and include the terms of financial assistance and the participant's commitment to maintain enrollment in the program of study. The participant must agree to accept financial assistance, maintain enrollment and attendance in the program of study, maintain acceptable academic standing, and serve as a full-time employee in the Department for three years after completing the program. Repayment is required if the individual fails to satisfy the agreement requirements, with the Secretary determining the amount to be repaid. The Secretary will establish procedures for repayment amounts and exceptions, waiver or suspension of obligations for noncompliance, and the obligation to repay as a debt to the United States. An obligation to repay the Secretary is considered a debt owed to the United States, and a discharge in bankruptcy does not discharge this debt if done within five years of the termination of the agreement or contract. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs must implement chapter 80 of title 38, United States Code within six months of the enactment of this Act.
